name: Green roof
description: Roofs that are covered with a lightweight, grass and plant layer with a shallow growing medium (usually less than 15 cm) that helps insulate buildings, provide habitat and increase the roof’s lifespan. They are not accessible for recreational use and require low maintenance

name: Green roof
description: Roofs that have deeper substrates (usually more than 15 cm) that can support a wide variety of plantings, such as shrubs, trees, flowers and vegetables. They are usually accessible for recreational use and require regular maintenance and irrigation

name: Green roof
types: Intensive green roof with retention layer
description: Roofs that have deeper substrates (usually more than 15 cm) that can support a wide variety of plantings, such as shrubs, trees, flowers and vegetables. They are usually accessible for recreational use and require regular maintenance and irrigation. Notably, they incorporate retention layers of up to 8 cm, providing additional water storage capacity but adding weight to the green roof.

name: Infiltration systems
description: Linear excavations filled with gravel or stone that create temporary subsurface storage of stormwater runoff, thereby enhancing the natural capacity of the ground to store and drain water. Infiltration trenches allow water to exfiltrate into the surrounding soils from the bottom and sides of the trench. They can be used in various soil types that can help distribute the infiltration area

name: Infiltration systems
description: Large shallow systems that are typically constructed using permeable aggregate or geocellular units that act as extensive soakaway systems. They are designed to enable or enhance the infiltration of surface water runoff into the ground, and can be used in isolation or as part of a 3D (multiple plane) infiltration system.

name: Infiltration systems
description: Flat-bottomed shallow landscape depressions that store runoff (allowing pollutants to settle and filter out) before infiltration into the subsurface soils. They are a form of engineered sump or percolation pond that is used to manage stormwater runoff, prevent flooding and downstream erosion, and improve water quality in an adjacent river, stream, lake or bay

name: Filter strips
description: Are uniformly graded and gently sloping strips of grass or other dense vegetation that are designed to treat runoff from adjacent impermeable areas by promoting sedimentation, filtration and infiltration. They are small, edge-of-field tracts of vegetated land that are used to reduce the contamination of surface water, especially from agricultural or construction activities. They can also serve as a buffer between incompatible land uses, and provide locations for groundwater recharge in areas with pervious soils

name: Swales
description: Conveyance and attenuation swales act similar to a pipeline in that they collect and carry surface water to the next stage in the SuDS management train. They are usually shallow and contain some vegetation, which means they can be used for both mitigation and treatment. If soil conditions permit and they are left unlined, they can also provide opportunities for infiltration. They have a larger storage capacity than filter drains and can attenuate peak flows by slowing down the runoff velocity

name: Swales
description: Wet swales are specifically designed to provide wet and/or boggy conditions at their base. As the system is often saturated, you will need to think carefully about your planting regime, using more water compatible vegetation at the base of the swale. Wet swales can enhance biodiversity and create habitats for wildlife. They can also provide some water quality treatment by facilitating biological processes that break down organic matter and nutrients

name: Bioretention systems
description: Rain gardens are small bioretention systems that serve part of a single property (roof or driveway). In simple rain gardens, filter and drainage layers are generally replaced by a thin layer of compost/sand-amended native soils or specified soil mixes. They usually have a simple inflow where rainwater enters the ground. Rain gardens can reduce runoff rates and volumes, and treat pollution through the use of engineered soils and vegetation

name: Bioretention systems
description: Raised planters are boxed systems constructed above the surrounding ground surface, with a planted soil mix and an underdrain to collect the filtered water. They are similar to bioretention systems but have less storage capacity and infiltration potential. They can be used in areas with high groundwater levels or contaminated soils. Raised planters can provide aesthetic benefits and some water quality treatment

name: Bioretention systems
description: A bioretention tree pit is a street tree pit with enhanced performance achieved through extra surface planting and soil amendments. It is designed to receive urban runoff water and improve its quality as the water passes through the soil. It can also provide aesthetic, ecological and climatic benefits for the urban environment

name: Bioretention systems
description: A bioretention swale is a shallow, vegetated, landscaped depression with sloped sides that is located within the base of a swale. It is designed to capture, treat and infiltrate stormwater runoff as it moves downstream. It can also convey stormwater when maximum ponding depth is exceeded. Bioretention swales incorporate the same design features as bioretention cells, such as filter media, vegetation, overflow weir and optional underdrain

name: Bioretention systems
description: A bioretention system that has the outlet pipe designed so that there is a permanent water level within the drainage layer, creating an anaerobic environment at the bottom of the system. The water storage allows the vegetation to access it during dry periods and it assists with treatment of some pollutants, especially nitrogen, through denitrification processes. Anaerobic bioretention systems can also remove E. coli from stormwater through filtration and adsorption

name: Trees
description: Trees can help protect and enhance the urban environment in a number of important ways, such as absorbing carbon dioxide and other pollutants, mitigating stormwater runoff, cooling the air and reducing energy use, providing habitat for wildlife, masking noise and unsightly views, and improving human health and well-being

name: Pervious pavements
description: A type of permeable paving that consists of modular units, such as concrete blocks, clay pavers, natural stone or plastic grids, that are laid on a permeable base and sub-base. Modular permeable paving allows water to infiltrate through the surface and reduce runoff quantity and peak rates. It can also provide aesthetic, structural and environmental benefits for the paved area

name: Pervious pavements
description: A type of ground protection that uses plastic or concrete grids infilled with grass or gravel to create a load-bearing, natural grass reinforced surface. Grass reinforcement is most suitable for lightly trafficked locations, especially where it only has seasonal use, so that the grass has time to recover. It is important that these systems are well constructed to ensure that the soils are not compacted and that the grass is suitable for the local climate. Grass reinforcement can offer benefits such as increased traction, improved slip resistance, reduced erosion, and enhanced aesthetics

name: Detention basins
description: Detention basins are landscaped depressions that are normally dry except during and immediately after storm events. They can be on-line components where surface runoff from regular events is routed through the basin and when the flows rise, because the outlet is restricted, the basin fills and provides storage of runoff and flow attenuation. They can also be off-line components into which runoff is diverted once flows reach a specified threshold.

name: Ponds and wetlands
description: They are features with a permanent pool of water that provide both attenuation and treatment of surface water runoff. They can support emergent and submerged aquatic vegetation along their shoreline and in shallow, marshy (wetland) zones, which helps enhance treatment processes and has amenity and biodiversity benefits.

name: Ponds and wetlands
description: It is the improvement or adaptation of an existing pond to function as a Sustainable Urban Drainage System (SUDS). The retrofitting may include the addition of a pretreatment, the modification of the depth or volume of the pond, the incorporation of aquatic or terrestrial vegetation, the installation of an outlet control or the enhancement of the landscaping
